titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the North Carolina Farm Bureau Records

controlnote.p: EAD generated by NCSU Libraries' Collection Guides application using data imported from ArchivesSpace.

maintenanceagency.agencyname: North Carolina State University Libraries, Special Collections Research Center

did.abstract: The bulk of these papers document the corporate activities of the North Carolina Farm Bureau between 1936 and 1999. The North Carolina Farm Bureau Federation, North Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company, North Carolina Farm Bureau Service Company, and North Carolina Farm Bureau Marketing Association are all represented in the documents of this collection. Also, a substantial amount of material testifies to the activities of the North Carolina Farm Bureau Women's Committee. Formats include correspondence, corporate documents, publications, financial ledgers, legal documents and transcripts, scrapbooks, photographs, film reels, audio recordings, and miscellaneous artifacts.

Organized in 1936 as a chapter of the American Farm Bureau, the North Carolina Farm Bureau was created to be a grassroots organization that would give farmers a unified voice on agricultural issues. Its Women's Committee was established in 1942. In 1953, the North Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company was established. Beginning in 1962, the North Carolina Farm Bureau pioneered creation of a group purchase program that was managed by the North Carolina Farm Bureau Service Company. The following year, the North Carolina Farm Bureau further expanded with the establishment of the North Carolina Farm Bureau Marketing Association. Because of the organization's involvement in legal and legislative matters, a Legal Foundation for the North Carolina Farm Bureau was created in 1983. In 1987, a Political Action Committee was also added. Educational programs of the Farm Bureau include the R. Flake Shaw Memorial Scholarship Fund, the Institute for Future Agricultural Leaders, and "Agriculture in the Classroom."
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Special Collections Research Center Reference Staff.

arrangement.p: The collection is divided into twelve series: Correspondence provides information on the Farm Bureau's relationship with county chapters of the organization, individual members, other state Farm Bureaus, and the American Farm Bureau Federation;Speeches and Statements made by Farm Bureau administrators;Organizational Documents for all of the five major divisions of the North Carolina Farm Bureau;Printed materials circulated by the North Carolina Farm Bureau and its major divisions, including handbooks, policies, reports, and pamphlets;Annual Meetings and Conferences contains materials relating to and collected at the organization's yearly conferences;Legal and Legislative Papers;Financial Materials;Reference Materials and Reports contains the various federal, state, corporate and non-profit resources used by the Farm Bureau for corporate research and political action research;Photograph series contains black and white prints of various people and buildings tied to the North Carolina Farm Bureau as well as two scrapbooks compiled by the organization for the years 1958 through 1960;Audiovisual series is comprised of film reels and recordings made by the Farm Bureau and utilized to present the organization's viewpoint on a certain agricultural issue;Artifacts collected by the North Carolina Farm Bureau;Additions.

bioghist.p: Organized in 1936 as a chapter of the American Farm Bureau, the North Carolina Farm Bureau was created to be a grassroots organization that would give farmers a unified voice on agricultural issues. Its Women's Committee was established in 1942. In 1953, the North Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company was established. Beginning in 1962, the North Carolina Farm Bureau pioneered creation of a group purchase program that was managed by the North Carolina Farm Bureau Service Company. The following year, the North Carolina Farm Bureau further expanded with the establishment of the North Carolina Farm Bureau Marketing Association. Because of the organization's involvement in legal and legislative matters, a Legal Foundation for the North Carolina Farm Bureau was created in 1983. In 1987, a Political Action Committee was also added. Educational programs of the Farm Bureau include the R. Flake Shaw Memorial Scholarship Fund, the Institute for Future Agricultural Leaders, and "Agriculture in the Classroom."

During the height of the Great Depression, a group of North Carolina farmers traveled to Washington in order to seek a solution to their many economic problems. They became aware of a need for mass organization through which they could work together to solve some of their problems. After researching the farming organizations of the time, these farmers decided to create a North Carolina chapter of the American Farm Bureau.

On March 2, 1936, the first meeting of the North Carolina Farm Bureau was called to order by Chairman J. E. Winslow. Although this initial meeting was held in Greenville, North Carolina, the organization elected to establish its headquarters at 403 Evans Street in Greensboro. An original membership numbered slightly over 2,000 people and represented 24 counties in eastern North Carolina. At the time, membership dues were $2.00 per member. In July 1936, the North Carolina Farm Bureau held its first annual meeting in Raleigh on the campus of North Carolina State College. By the time of this meeting, membership had grown to 4,490 members from 30 counties.

Throughout the 1940s, membership in the North Carolina Farm Bureau continued to grow. By 1944, the organization had 30,000 members, thus fulfilling the quota set by the American Farm Bureau Federation. By the end of the decade, the North Carolina Farm Bureau led the South in membership statistics. Administrators also furthered participation by establishing a Women's Committee for the organization in 1942.

In 1953, the North Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company was established. The initial offering was limited to casualty lines. However, by the next year, members could receive life and annuity insurance through Southern Farm Bureau Life. Later additions to the insurance programs authorized fire lines and crop insurance. Later in the 1950s, the Farm Bureau elected to move its headquarters to Raleigh, where they inhabited the former Raleigh Times building.

Under the guidance of President B.C. Mangum, in 1962, the North Carolina Farm Bureau pioneered the creation of a group purchase program that would soon be adopted by other Farm Bureau chapters across the country. Managed by the newly-formed North Carolina Farm Bureau Service Company, this program offered a variety of Safemark products, including tires and batteries, to Bureau members at a substantial discount.

The following year, the North Carolina Farm Bureau furthered its expansion with the establishment of the North Carolina Farm Bureau Marketing Association. Involved in a number of commodity programs since its inception, the association provided farmers with the opportunity to strengthen both their marketing and bargaining powers. The initial focus of this sector was the hog market, however, markets for dairy products, broiler hens, and a variety of fruits and vegetables have also enjoyed success as a result of this program.

The 1970s proved to be another decade of growth for the Farm Bureau. The organization outgrew its initial Raleigh headquarters, and in 1971, moved to its current location on Glenwood Avenue. Later construction in 1980 and 1992 would even further expand this location. By 1974, membership had expanded to over 100,000 members.

Because of the organization's great involvement in legal and legislative matters, a Legal Foundation for the North Carolina Farm Bureau was created in 1983. In 1987, a Political Action Committee was also added. Recently, the Farm Bureau has established several programs that serve the educational needs of young people interested in a career in agriculture. Since 1958, the Farm Bureau has provided financial assistance to agriculture students through the R. Flake Shaw Memorial Scholarship Fund. In 1984, the North Carolina Farm Bureau, in conjunction with North Carolina State University, launched the Institute for Future Agricultural Leaders, which offers high school students the opportunity to attend a summer seminar on the prospects of a career in agriculture. The organization also soon added an "Agriculture in the Classroom" program that integrates ag-related curriculum into traditional courses of study.

prefercite.p: [Identification of Item], North Carolina Farm Bureau Records, MC 313, Special Collections Research Center, North Carolina State University Libraries, Raleigh, North Carolina.

scopecontent.p: The bulk of these papers document the corporate activities of the North Carolina Farm Bureau between 1936 and 1999. The North Carolina Farm Bureau Federation, North Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company, North Carolina Farm Bureau Service Company, and North Carolina Farm Bureau Marketing Association are all represented in the documents of this collection. Also, a substantial amount of material testifies to the activities of the North Carolina Farm Bureau Women's Committee. Formats include correspondence, corporate documents, publications, financial ledgers, legal documents and transcripts, scrapbooks, photographs, film reels, audio recordings, and miscellaneous artifacts.

userestrict.p: North Carolina State University does not own copyright to this collection. Individuals obtaining materials from the NCSU Libraries' Special Collections Research Center are responsible for using the works in conformance with United States copyright law as well as any donor restrictions accompanying the materials.

North Carolina Farm Bureau Service Company

scopecontent.p: Correspondence contained in this collection details the everyday activities and concerns of the North Carolina Farm Bureau. The earliest letters date back to 1947; however, the majority of the correspondence in this collection dates from the 1970s and 1980s. Letters from 1954 to 1966 were not acessioned with this collection, and all 1968 correspondence was reported missing by the Farm Bureau in October of 1985. Much of the correspondence includes letters from the president of the North Carolina Farm Bureau Federation to county chapters, individual members, and state polticians requesting support on a particular legislative issue. The series also contains a number of letters from other state farm bureaus and the American Farm Bureau Federation. Correspondence from the insurance, marketing, and service divisions are also included.

The three boxes in this series include speeches made by North Carolina Farm Bureau administrators at local and national Farm Bureau-sponsored events, as well as statements issued by the organization in reference to a certain legislative issue. The statements usually refer to national petitions and were read by a North Carolina Farm Bureau representative in Washington. Although some speeches and statements from the 1950s and 1960s are represented in this collection, documents from the 1970s and 1980s are dominant. Issues represented in this series range from local concerns over the dairy industry in North Carolina, to national legislation on tobacco and the taxation of cigarettes.

One of the largest series of the collection, organizational documents details a wide array of corporate activities undertaken by the North Carolina Farm Bureau. This series is divided into five main subseries, each of which represent the main division of the Farm Bureau. The first and largest of these is the North Carolina Farm Bureau Federation. Within this subseries, historical and biographical sketches of the organization and its leaders are provided. Also included is basic information regarding committees, membership statistics, and awards programs. The next subseries gives a basic overview of the creation and objectives of the North Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company. Third, a chronological arrangement of County Participation in the TBA Program provides insight into the inner workings of the North Carolina Farm Bureau Service Company. The next subseries focuses on the North Carolina Farm Bureau Marketing Association. In this subseries, each of the marketing programs, which range from hog marketing to dairy marketing, are listed and foldered individually. Finally, a complete listing of the minutes and other corporate documents of the North Carolina Farm Bureau Women's Committee are provided in the last subseries.

scopecontent.p: The series of Printed Materials is divided into subseries that represent the major divisions of the North Carolina Farm Bureau. For the North Carolina Farm Bureau Federation, the primary document circulated through the organization was its annual policies. Arranged chronologically, these policies document the resolutions adopted by the Farm Bureau at its annual meetings. Often times, these policies also reflect and approve national resolutions proposed by the American Farm Bureau Federation. The Federation subseries also includes miscellaneous propaganda pamphlets circulated by the organization. The next subseries lists the General Manager's Reports for the North Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company. Although the chronological list reveals several lapses, this subseries does contain all reports accessioned with the collection. Third, the printed materials circulated by the North Carolina Farm Bureau Service Company are dominated by price lists for Safemark products offered by the program. Finally, the subseries for the North Carolina Farm Bureau Women's Committee contains handbooks that reveal the goals and objectives of the group.

scopecontent.p: This series focuses on the materials collected at and pertaining to the annual meetings and other miscellaneous conferences sponsored by the North Carolina Farm Bureau. Remarks by the President of both the North Carolina Farm Bureau Federation and the North Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance are included.

did.unittitle: North Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company
Text of Remarks by the President of the United States
Other State and Regional Farm Bureaus

scopecontent.p: The largest series of the collection, this group of records elaborates upon the many legal, legislative, and financial undertakings of the North Carolina Farm Bureau. Topics include legislation of issues regarding cotton, dairy, livetsock, peanuts, and poultry. Tobacco legislation dominates the subseries of legal materials, indicating the emphasis and importance the Farm Bureau placed on this often controversial topic.

Financial Materials includes records of membership dues for each county. The bulk of these records detail statistics from 1940-1970. Several original ledgers and bank registers of the organization are also included in this series. These ledgers have been split into four main subgroups: payments, disbursements, income, and receipts. In the case of many ledgers, the organization kept several records for a particular year, hence the overlapping dates for many of the ledgers.

scopecontent.p: Reference Materials and Reports reflect the wide body of research amassed by the Farm Bureau with regard to a variety of agricultural issues. Materials contain reports and publications produced by the North Carolina Farm Bureau and other national organizations. Publications are broken down by the publishing agency, such as the United States Department of Agriculture, the American Farm Bureau Federation, and the North Carolina Department of Agriculture. Publications are also grouped by subject matter when they refer to a certain agricutural topic such as cotton, peanuts, or tobacco. Materials grouped by subject matter come from a variety of publishing agencies, including internal reports to the North Carolina Farm Bureau and information from governmental, corporate, and non-profit organizations.

scopecontent.p: The photograph series is split into two subseries. The first of these is comprised of black and white prints of various Farm Bureau leaders and buildings. The second subseries of the photograph collection contains two scrapbooks compiled by the North Carolina Farm Bureau for the years 1958-1959 and 1959-1960. These scrapbooks include black and white photographs taken at various Farm Bureau events as well as newspaper articles citing the organization.

scopecontent.p: The audiovisual series contains a sound recording performed for the Farm Bureau by the Purdue University Marching Band, and film reels and videocassettes on various agricultural issues.

scopecontent.p: The artifacts series is comprised of a variety of items compiled by the Farm Bureau during the history of their organization. The majority of the artifacts are pins awarded to Farm Bureau members. Other items include guest books from Farm Bureau events and framed memorabilia.

did.unittitle: North Carolina Farm Bureau Silver Tie Bar
North Carolina Farm Bureau Silver Button
2 Guest Books signed at North Carolina Farm Bureau Building Dedication, 1971
Framed Copy of 1942 Congressional Record testifying "Who the Farm Bureau Works For"

scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, reports, meeting notes, committee and board minutes, brochures, press releases and clippings, and other items related to both the North Carolina Farm Bureau and other farm organizations, including the American Farm Bureau Federation. These materials have been arranged by type of material except where topical arrangement was more efficient.
